An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
Does the concept of a/an Greatest common divisor need to be defined for a definition of a/an Principal Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Principal Ideal involves the set of all multiples of a given element $a$ in a ring $R$, denoted as $Ra$. This set is defined purely in terms of the ring operations and the element $a$. It does not inherently require any notion of divisibility among multiple elements, nor does it require comparing the divisibility of one element by others, which are central to the concept of a Greatest Common Divisor (GCD).

The GCD concept, on the other hand, involves finding an element $d$ that divides multiple elements $x_1, 
ldots, x_n$ in the most comprehensive way possible, and also being divisible by any other common divisor of these elements. This concept is fundamentally about relationships between multiple elements in terms of divisibility.

Thus, the definition and understanding of a Principal Ideal can be fully grasped and utilized without any reference to or need for the concept of a GCD. The Principal Ideal focuses on the generation of an ideal by a single element, while the GCD deals with the interrelationships in divisibility among multiple elements.
